subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear

messageBody:
Terry Smithwick wrote:
>
>
> One way to look at it is that in certain contexts,
> American speech can have a 'b' sound which is
> understood to be a 'p'.
> This is phonemic variation, a common attribute of
> languages in which ordinary (not careful or formal)
> speech confuses sounds in a context that is inherently
> not confusing enough to matter -- to the speakers.
>
> IPA is an overprecise way of specifying the exact
> sound generated. Most American phonemes can take on
> several different IPA sounds depending on context -
> usually the preceding or sometimes following sound.
>
> Look at it this way - after a short period of
> assimilation, a Texan can understand a Brooklyn
> speaker and a Californian Valley speaker - both of
> which have widely varying pronunciations (and
> intonations) of words.
>
> Thus, a QS reader should be able to 'catch on' to
> the phonemic variations in any ordinary dialect with
> minimal confusion.
>
> The major problem for the phonetic reader is that
> pacing and intonation are not present in the written
> word, and these can be clues to meaning. However, this
> information is almost never a determining factor, thus
> are not phonemic in English.

But all that doesn't really matter, and it misses my point. (I have
written a detailed response to Page up above.) We don't need for QS to
be as precise as IPA. A true IPA rendering actually would render
different transcriptions for the same word in different parts of the
sentence. We don't need that.

What we need is a precise way to describe the sound of each letter.
Right now the method is absurd. The revised alphabet, for example,
proscribes that you pronounce #34 as "on." But look up this word at
dictionary.com, and you see that "on" can be pronounced as #33 as well!
So a learner of QS comes across bad information right away. We on this
mailing list also have a weak foundation for all our discussion. We talk
about the merging of #32, #33, and #34, but what sounds do these
represent? We can't say! Certainly, we can't say that #34 sounds like
such and such a word, because each person pronounces that word differently.

Right now there is no mechanism to accurately describe QS letters
(really only the vowels). The IPA can describe each letter; I am aware
of no other system that can do the same.

Really, I don't see my proposal as that radical. Right now we talk about
#34 and give it a name. Presumably, we all have the same exact sound in
our mind. If we went to a coffee house and listened carefully for
several hours, we should all be able to point out what words, when
spoken, contained #34. Or we could point out that #34 is not spoken in
this region. So why shouldn't we agree to a mapping that identifies it
precisely rather than using the broken method of saying "well, it sounds
like x?"

Paul
